questions.question: This command initializes a new Git repository.
This command stages changes for the next commit.
This command saves your staged changes to the repository history.
This command shows the status of changed files.
This command lists the commit history.
This command creates a new branch.
This command switches to a different branch.
This command merges a branch into the current one.
This command creates and switches to a new branch in one step.
This command deletes a branch.
This command downloads changes from a remote repository.
This command uploads local changes to a remote repository.
This command copies a remote repository to your local machine.
This command adds a new remote repository.
This command shows the remote URLs.
This command temporarily saves your changes without committing.
This command reapplies commits on top of another base tip.
This command finds the commit that introduced a bug.
This command removes untracked files from the working tree.
This command shows who changed what and when in a file.
A popular branching model for Git.
A request to merge code into the main codebase.
A copy of a repository that you manage.
The default branch name in modern Git repositories.
A file that specifies intentionally untracked files to ignore.
This hidden folder contains all Git repository data.
This type of Git object stores the contents of a file.
This Git object type represents a directory listing.
This command shows the type of a Git object.
This file in .git stores the current branch reference.
This command unstages a file.
This command discards local changes to a file.
This command creates a new commit that undoes a previous commit.
This reset mode keeps changes in the working directory.
This command lets you rewrite commit history interactively.
This command fetches and merges remote changes.
This command downloads remote changes without merging.
This Git feature lets multiple remotes be configured.
This command shows all remote-tracking branches.
This command sets the upstream branch for pushing.
This command sets your Git username.
This flag makes a config setting apply to all repositories.
This command lists all configuration settings.
This config file is stored in your home directory.
This command creates a Git alias.
This command applies a single commit from another branch.
This command compresses the repository history.
This command shows the reference log of HEAD movements.
This command lists all tags in a repository.
This command manages multiple working trees.

finalJeopardy.clue: This Finnish software engineer created Git in 2005 to manage Linux kernel development after the BitKeeper license was revoked.
